dict.string: {_site_ruby} are intended to hold modules and extensions that you have added. The architecture-dependent directories (x86_64-darwin12.4.0) hold executables and other things spacific to this particular machine. all these directories are automatically include in Ruby's search for libraries.
{$:} is an array of places to search for loaded files. plus any additional ones you specified using RUBYLIB and -l. You can always add directories to this array from with your running program.

[Ruby find its library]  require or load to bring a library into the Ruby program. Some amy have been packaged as RubyGems and some you may have written yourself. How does ruby find them>?  ruby -e 'puts $:'
{Writing to Environment Variables} A ruby program may write to ENV object. However, this change is local to the process that makes it and to any subsequently spawned child processes.

[Environment Variables] Can access operating system environment variables using the predefined variable ENV.(xxx). It responds to the same methods as Hashes. The values of some environment variables are read by Ruby when it first starts. These variables modify the behaviour of the interpreter.
In the Gem world, developers bundle their applications and libraries into single files called gems. These files conform to a standardised format and typically are stored in repository on the net.
RubyGems system provide a command-line tool, appropriately named gem, for manipulating these gem files.

--details displays the description of any gems it finds --remote searches the remote repository --name-matches search the central gem repository for any gem whose name matches the regular expression /build/
{Installing Gems}  gem query --details --remote --name-matches build
{check the local gems} gem list
Create a shortcut? % gemdoc='gem environment gemdir'/doc ls $gemdoc open $gemdoc/xxxxxxxx/rdoc/index.html
Easyest way to view the RDoc documentation is to use RubyGems' included gem server utility. %gem server

{Reading the Gem Documentation} the documentation for each gem is stored in a central,protected,RUBYgeMS-SPECIFIC PLACE.  % gem environment gemdir  RubyGems stores generated documentation beneath the doc subfolder and you will find the HTML based files.
[Using a Gem] Once a gem is installed, user {require} to load it into your own code, just s you would any other Ruby library.
the magic is gem line, which says, "when looking for the builder gem, consider only those versions less than 1.0"
the multiple version predicates is also validate  gem 'builder' , '> .01', '< 0.1.5'

[Gems and Versions]  asked for a listing of Builder gems in the repository  % gem list -ra builder  // install the builder which version is less than 1 % gem install builder --version '< 1' % gem list builder
[RubyGems Integration] It is a standardised packaging and installation framework for Ruby libraries and applications. RubyGems makes it easy to locate, install , upgrade and uninstall Ruby packages.
require 'rbconfig' include Config CONFIG["host"]… …..

[Build Environment]  When ruby is compiled for a particular architecture, all the relevant settings used to build it (including the architecture of the machine o which it was compiled, compiler options source del directory, and so on) are written to the module Config within the library file rbconfig.rb. After installation, any Ruby program can use this module to get details on how Ruby was compiled:
{AWS:S3} gem is a library that gives you programmatic access to Amazon's S3 storage facility.  {s3sh} lets you interact with s3 assets.
Although gems supports versioning of libraries, it does not version command-line utilities. With these, "last one in wins."
[Gems can be more than library]  RubyGems can also install utility programs that you can invoke from the command line.
lets package this code as {task} - a chunk of code that Rake can execute for us
By default, rake searches the current directory (and its parents) for a file called {Rakefile} - the file contain the definitions for the tasks that Rake can run.
{desc} provides a single line of documentation for the task that follows it.

{task} defines a Rake task that can be executed from the command line. The parameter is the name of the task(a symbol) , and the block that follows is the code to be executed.  Here just need rm - all the methods if FileUtils are automatically available inside Rake files.
it does not have an .rb extension, this is actually just a file of Ruby code. Rake defines an environment containing methods such as {desc} and {task} and then executes the Rakefile.

Rake was initially implemented as a Ruby version of Make, the common build utility.  Rake is an automation tool- it is a way of putting all those tasks that you perform in a project into one neat and tidy place.
[The Rake Build Tool]  Jim Weirich wrote an incredibly useful utility program called Rake.
ruby [ options ] [ -- ] [ program file name ] [ arguments ]
{Command Line Options}
{ARGV} any command-line arguments after the grogram filename are available to your Ruby program in the global array ARGV.

There’s a gotcha here for all you C programmers—ARGV[0] is the first argument to the program, not the program name. The name of the current program is available in the global variable $0, which is aliased to $PROGRAM_NAME. Notice that all the values in ARGV are strings.

If your program reads from standard input (or uses the special object ARGF, described on page 342), the program arguments in ARGV will be taken to be filenames, and Ruby will read from these files. If your program takes a mixture of arguments and filenames, make sure you empty the nonfilename arguments from the ARGV array before reading from the files.

The name of the current program is available in the global variable \fs22 $0 \fs24 , which is aliased to \fs22 $PROGRAM_NAME \fs24 . If your program takes a mixture of arguments and filenames, make sure you empty the nonfilename arguments from the \fs22 ARGV \fs24 array before reading from the files.\ }
[Command Line Arguments]  A ruby command line consists three parts: 1.options to the Ruby interpreter 2.optionally the name of a program to run 3.optionally a set of arguments for that program
[Program Termination] Kernel#exit terminates your program.
